nodes.text: The relative interference of simultaneous conflicting word and color stimuli reveals that associations linking printed words to the reading response are stronger than associations linking colors to the naming response, and that practice modifies these interference effects asymmetrically

Method: Simultaneously present word stimuli and color stimuli using stimuli where color names are printed in ink of a different color, plus control forms with words in black and colors in neutral shapes; measure time to read words or name ink-colors serially

Experiment 1 design: Compare reading time for 100 color-name words printed in conflicting ink colors (RCNd) versus same words printed in black (RCNb); 70 undergraduate subjects with balanced test order and timing procedures

Experiment 2 design: Compare naming time for 100 ink-colors when colors are printed as squares (NC) versus when colors are the ink of printed color-name words (NCWd); 100 students, controlled order and error corrections

Experiment 3 design: Give practice (daily trials naming ink-colors of words, NCWd) to 32 subjects over multiple days and measure effects on NCWd performance, on NC (colors in shapes), and on RCNd (reading words printed in conflicting ink-colors)

Operational definitions: Interference of color on reading = increase in time reading words in conflicting ink-colors versus black; Interference of words on color naming = increase in time naming ink-colors of printed words versus colors in shapes
Materials control: Five colors used (red, blue, green, brown, purple), balanced appearance order, two test forms, controlled lighting and starting cues, sample trials and timing to fifth of a second

Result (Experiment 1): Reading 100 color-name words printed in conflicting ink-colors took on average 2.3 seconds (5.6%) longer than reading same words printed in black; this increase was small and not statistically reliable

Result (Experiment 2): Naming 100 ink-colors when presented as printed words (NCWd) increased mean time from 63.3 to 110.3 seconds (an increase of 47.0 seconds or 74.3%), a large and highly reliable interference effect of word stimuli on color naming

Result (Experiment 3, practice on NCWd): Eight short practice sessions on NCWd produced a mean gain of 16.8 seconds (33.9%) on NCWd, a smaller transfer gain on NC of 4.0 seconds (13.9%), increased variability on NCWd, and increased interference of colors on word reading (RCNd) measured as loss of speed

Result (Experiment 3, reversibility): Newly developed interference from practice on NCWd to RCNd was rapidly reversed by brief practice on RCNd, indicating asymmetry in ease of strengthening versus renewing prior associations

Evidence synthesis: Word-reading associations produced minimal interference when color conflicted with reading (small nonreliable effect), whereas habitual word-reading responses produced strong interference on color naming (large reliable effect); practice on color naming of word-prints reduces but does not eliminate interference and transfers partially to naming colors in shapes

Evidence: Practice increased between-subject variability on the difficult NCWd task but practice decreased variability on the easier RCNd reading task, suggesting practice effects depend on task complexity and initial variability

Conclusion: The strength difference between word-reading and color-naming associations largely reflects differential training: reading responses are strongly and specifically associated with printed words, while colors elicit varied response tendencies; practice can strengthen weaker associations but asymmetrically and with partial transfer

Implication and limitation: The results support an account of the classic color-word interference based on learned associative strength and training history; limitations include subject samples mainly college students, limited color set, and short practice duration
